metadata.titleEn: Ring-width indices and annual water deficit anomaly of the southwest USA (1902-2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset is collected from the  Supplementary Materials part of the paper: Gao, S., Zhou, T., Yi, C., Shi, P., Fang, W., Liu, R., Liang, E., & Julio Camarero, J. (2020). Asymmetric impacts of dryness and wetness on tree growth and forest coverage. Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 288-289, 107980. doi:10.1016/j.agrformet.2020.107980.
In this paper the researchers took forests in the semi-arid area of the Colorado Plateau in the southwest USA as the research object, comprehensively applied a large amount of tree ring width data, combined with remote sensing forest coverage data, they explored the legacy effect under the influence of the interannual water deficit by designing "natural experiments" at the regional scale, and compared the similarities and differences of the effect of the interannual water status changes on the tree ring width and forest coverage. The study found that the water status in the year when the tree ring was formed can significantly affect the duration and intensity of the legacy effect, and the response of the tree ring width and forest coverage to the interannual water status is different. 
This data contains ring-width indices (RWI) of 357 sample sites in 111-hydrological year (i.e., for 1902–2012) and annual water deficit anomaly (Dya) that matched to RWI.
The tree-ring database used in this research was composed of 357 standard chronologies of three major species (Pinus edulis Engelm., Pinus ponderosa Douglas ex C. Lawson and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Mirb.) Franco) in the study region, spanning from 1902 to 2012, resulting in a total of 29,969 site-years. A total of 357 tree-ring width chronologies of three major tree species were obtained from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank (https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access/paleoclimatology-data/datasets/tree-ring). To transform tree-ring width data into ring-width indices (RWI), long-term trends caused by aging and increasing trunk diameter were mostly removed by negative exponential curves using the ARSTAN program (Cook, 1985). After performing standardization, all chronologies were scaled to a standard mean (RWI = 1000) with a comparable variance to reduce the spatial heterogeneity among these tree-ring sites.
In this research, researchers used annual water deficit anomaly (Dya) to explore the impact of water deficit variability on tree radial growth and growth legacies. They matched gridded Dya to RWIs. For tree-ring chronologies within the same grid, they averaged them for each year to reduce bias caused by the rough resolution of climate data.
The data is 1 Excel workbooks, Ring-width indices and annual water deficit anomaly (1902-2012), which contains 3 worksheets as follows:
raw_data
processed_data
variables
The data contains the following fields:
sitename: the name of tree-ring sampled site
Year: the tree-ring formation year
RWI: ring-width indices
latitude: the latitude of tree-ring sampled site
lontitude: the lontitude of tree-ring sampled site
altitude: the altitude of tree-ring sampled site
lon Grid no.: the lontitude grid number of tree-ring sampled site
lat Grid no.: the latitude grid number of tree-ring sampled site
Dya_3: water deficit anomaly of the 3rd year before the tree-ring formation year (i.e. "Year" column) 
Dya_2: water deficit anomaly of the 2nd year before the tree-ring formation year (i.e. "Year" column) 
Dya_1: water deficit anomaly of the 1st year before the tree-ring formation year (i.e. "Year" column) 
Dya_curr: water deficit anomaly of the tree-ring formation year (i.e. "Year" column) 
Dya_std: the standard  deviation of 111-hydrological year (i.e., for 1902–2012) averaged annual water deficit of the grid
metadata.instructions: This dataset contains 1 Excel workbook: Ring-width indices and annual water deficit anomaly (1902-2012), the data can be viewed and edited by Excel software of Microsoft Office.

background: The prevalence of legacy effects, especially in drought-prone forests, makes the accurate assessment of forest dynamics under frequent climate fluctuations challenging. Forest ecosystems are becoming increasingly vulnerable in the face of climate change, especially in semiarid regions. Intensified drought stress, now generally agreed upon as the most widespread and frequent threat to many forests, has led to recent higher tree mortality rate and forest die-off episodes. Although a meteorological water budget can be constantly monitored, its impacts on tree growth and forest dynamics are quite uncertain. One important reason is the pervasive existence of legacies (i.e. the lagged responses to extreme events) in forest ecosystems. Observational research generally revealed 1- to 4-year long legacies recorded in tree-rings at regional to global scales and presented the recovery process of tree growth after droughts. Similarly, the enhancement of radial growth after extreme wetness could also be observed for 1 to 5 years. So far, most related studies focused on lagged impacts of past extreme years or events on current growth; however, current water condition immediately influence current growth, which may alter or offset the ecological impacts of past extremes. In addition, despite the abundance of evidence on the significant legacy effects recorded in tree-rings, whether these growth legacies could be upscaled to the level of a whole forest have not been fully discussed.
research objective: In this study, we (1) examined the temporal dynamics of legacy effects recorded in tree-rings with the consideration of both past and current water deficit conditions, and (2) compared legacy effects on both tree-ring widths and forest coverage change to expand our understanding of forest dynamics in response to climate from both spatial scales. We hypothesized that the temporal pattern of legacy effect changes when effects from multiple years are superimposed on top of one another. We also hypothesized that the response of tree growth to the shift of interannual water deficit condition is rapid and intense, but forest coverage does not have obvious changes in a short period.
challenges: The representativeness of tree-ring data in the ITRDB has been questioned: some studies pointed out that tree-ring data in the ITRDB significantly overestimate regional forest climate sensitivity due to the specific selection of sampling sites. Updating more metadata (e.g., diameter at breast height, microenvironment information) of sampled trees in the ITRDB can help to clarify these uncertainties.
methods: We designed a series of regional-scaled “natural experiments”, specifically, we preset hypothetical water conditions of current- and antecedent-hydrological years and conducted quantitative analysis on grouped tree-ring records and sub-pixel changes of forest coverage under these conditions. We used FCC data to further study the impacts of inter-annual water deficit on forest coverage dynamics. We first set selection criteria (normal, wet or dry) to water deficit conditions of the current and its previous year, and then grouped FCC data according to those criteria so analysis could be conducted among those groups.
dataset: A total of 357 tree-ring width chronologies of three major tree species (Pinus edulis Engelm., Pinus ponderosa Douglas ex C. Lawson and Pseudotsuga menziesii (Mirb.) Franco) were obtained from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank. The study region contained 3388 PFPs, spanning from 2002 to 2017, resulting in a total of 54,208 FCC data.
findings: Results showed that the temporal patterns of growth legacy changed dynamically when studying it on multiple events level (i.e., both past and current climate condition are taken into consideration): under current-hydrological year dry conditions, legacy effects over 3 years could be detected; while under current-hydrological year wet conditions, only previous 1 year's legacy could be detected, and its intensity was only 57% of that under current-hydrological year dry conditions. Furthermore, our results revealed that growth dynamics observed in tree rings were not fully consistent with the dynamic of forest coverage. Wetness enhanced growth pronouncedly, whereas normal to wet conditions only barely maintained the stability of forest coverage, suggesting that tree growth is more sensitive to wetness than forest coverage. In addition, the impact of consecutive dry years on tree radial growth showed no significant difference from that of a single dry year, but the decline of forest coverage accelerated after consecutive droughts.

Verification.Question: Does the representativeness of tree-ring data in the International Tree-Ring Data Bank face challenges due to the selection of sampling sites?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary challenges in using tree-ring data from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank for assessing regional forest climate sensitivity?
Where can researchers find datasets on tree-ring width indices for studying forest dynamics in response to climate fluctuations?
What methods are used to match tree-ring width indices with annual water deficit anomalies in the context of studying forest dynamics?

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how datasets can be expanded or refined to improve the understanding of forest dynamics under climate fluctuations?
Example.Answer: To refine datasets, integrating more metadata such as tree diameter and microenvironmental information for sampled trees could improve the understanding of forest dynamics. Additionally, matching grid-level climatological data with tree-ring indices can help reduce biases from coarse climate data resolution, thus enhancing the dataset's accuracy in reflecting forest dynamics.

Feature Specification.Question: What factors are considered when designing natural experiments for assessing tree growth responses to water deficit conditions?
Feature Specification.Answer: current and antecedent hydrological year conditions, preset criteria for normal, wet, or dry conditions, tree-ring records grouping, superimposed effects of multiple years' climatic conditions

Quantification.Question: How many sampling points are used to collect data on tree-ring widths and water deficit anomalies in the specified semi-arid region?

Definition.Question: What does 'natural experiments' mean in the context of analyzing forest dynamics?
Definition.Answer: 'Natural experiments' in this context refer to the designed regional-scaled studies where hypothetical water conditions of current and antecedent hydrological years are preset, allowing for the quantitative analysis of tree-ring records and forest coverage changes under these conditions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods of tree-ring width indices from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank compare to the methods used for collecting annual water deficit anomaly data?
Comparison.Answer: Tree-ring width indices are collected using standardized procedures from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank, where tree-ring data is standardized using the ARSTAN program to remove age-related trends. In contrast, annual water deficit anomaly data is derived from grid-based meteorological data, which is matched to the tree-ring data to assess the impact of drought conditions on tree growth.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when assessing legacy effects using tree-ring data compared to forest coverage data?
Comparison.Answer: Tree-ring data faces challenges such as the potential overestimation of regional forest climate sensitivity due to site selection bias in the International Tree-Ring Data Bank, and the need for more metadata to clarify these uncertainties. Conversely, forest coverage data challenges involve analyzing sub-pixel changes and accounting for the impact of inter-annual water deficit on forest dynamics, which may not align with tree-ring growth patterns.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of standardized tree-ring width indices influence the interpretation of long-term forest dynamics in a semi-arid region?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of standardized tree-ring width indices helps mitigate the effects of aging and tree diameter increase, allowing researchers to more accurately assess interannual variations in tree growth and their responses to water deficit anomalies, thus providing a clearer understanding of long-term forest dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can arise from the use of existing tree-ring data banks in assessing the accuracy of forest climate sensitivity and how might researchers address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Existing tree-ring data banks may overestimate regional forest climate sensitivity due to selective sampling sites. Researchers can address these challenges by updating metadata such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment information of sampled trees to improve the representativeness and accuracy of the data.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be gained from comparing legacy effects on tree-ring widths versus forest coverage changes, and how might this comparison influence future forest management strategies?
Interpretation.Answer: Comparing legacy effects on tree-ring widths and forest coverage changes reveals that tree growth is more sensitive to wet conditions than forest coverage. This insight could influence future forest management strategies by highlighting the need for targeted interventions during wet periods to enhance tree growth and maintain forest stability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors might cause variability in tree-ring data from different sampling sites, and how can these be mitigated?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The representativeness of tree-ring data in the International Tree-Ring Data Bank (ITRDB) has been questioned due to the specific selection of sampling sites. This variability can be mitigated by updating more metadata, such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment information, of sampled trees in the ITRDB to clarify these uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do legacy effects in tree growth differ under varying hydrological conditions and how does this impact data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Legacy effects in tree growth differ under varying hydrological conditions because, under current-hydrological year dry conditions, legacy effects over three years can be detected, whereas under wet conditions, only the previous year's legacy can be detected, with reduced intensity. This variance impacts data collection by necessitating the consideration of both past and current water deficit conditions to accurately assess forest dynamics.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of more comprehensive metadata, such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment details, affect the interpretation of tree-ring data in understanding forest climate sensitivity?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including more comprehensive metadata could help clarify uncertainties regarding the representativeness of tree-ring data, potentially leading to more accurate interpretations of forest climate sensitivity. This could address concerns that current datasets overestimate regional climate sensitivity due to specific site selections.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of examining the temporal dynamics of legacy effects recorded in tree-rings in relation to both past and current water deficit conditions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to expand the understanding of forest dynamics in response to climate by examining how legacy effects on tree-ring widths and forest coverage change under different water deficit conditions, and to hypothesize that the response of tree growth to these interannual conditions is rapid and intense compared to forest coverage.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to compare the legacy effects on tree-ring widths and forest coverage change?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to compare these legacy effects to understand the differential responses of tree growth and forest coverage to climate conditions, as tree growth is hypothesized to be more sensitive to wetness than forest coverage, which could lead to a better understanding of forest dynamics at different spatial scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended objectives of conducting natural experiments to study the impacts of inter-annual water deficit on forest coverage dynamics?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended objectives are to conduct quantitative analysis on grouped tree-ring records and sub-pixel changes of forest coverage under preset hypothetical water conditions, in order to study how different water deficit conditions affect forest coverage dynamics and to understand the ecological impacts of past and current extremes on forest ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in standardizing and scaling tree-ring width data to account for aging and diameter growth before analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The tree-ring width data is standardized using the ARSTAN program by applying a negative exponential curve to eliminate long-term trends caused by aging and diameter growth. After standardization, all chronologies are scaled to a standard mean with comparable variance (RWI = 1000) to reduce spatial heterogeneity among tree-ring sites.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the matching of grid-based water deficit anomaly data with tree-ring width indices achieved to minimize biases due to coarse climate data resolution?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Grid-based annual water deficit anomaly data is matched with tree-ring width indices by averaging tree-ring records within the same grid annually. This approach helps to reduce biases that may arise from the coarse spatial resolution of climate data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is used to design regional-scaled 'natural experiments' to assess the impact of inter-annual water deficit on forest coverage dynamics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Regional-scaled 'natural experiments' are designed by setting hypothetical water conditions for current and antecedent hydrological years, and conducting quantitative analysis on grouped tree-ring records and sub-pixel changes in forest coverage under these conditions. Forest coverage change (FCC) data is grouped according to selection criteria for water deficit conditions (normal, wet, or dry) to facilitate comparative analysis.

Enablement.Question: What conditions might enable the refinement of metadata in datasets derived from tree-ring data banks to address uncertainties in forest climate sensitivity?
Enablement.Answer: Updating metadata with information such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment conditions of sampled trees could help clarify uncertainties related to the representativeness of tree-ring data in the International Tree-Ring Data Bank.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of 'natural experiments' enhance the understanding of legacy effects on tree growth and forest coverage?
Enablement.Answer: Designing regional-scaled 'natural experiments' allows for the analysis of tree-ring records and forest coverage changes under predefined hypothetical water conditions, thereby enhancing the understanding of legacy effects under different hydrological scenarios.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of tree-ring width data with grid-based water deficit anomalies to investigate the impact on radial growth?
Enablement.Answer: Matching grid-based annual water deficit anomalies with tree-ring width indices and averaging these within the same grid to reduce bias from coarse climate data resolution enables the investigation of impacts on radial growth.

Expectation.Question: Why might the anticipated impact of water deficit conditions on forest coverage dynamics differ from that on tree growth dynamics in data analysis?
Expectation.Answer: The findings indicate that tree growth shows a more pronounced response to wetness, whereas forest coverage remains relatively stable under normal to wet conditions. This suggests that tree growth is more sensitive to changes in moisture levels compared to forest coverage.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for the anticipated sensitivity of tree-ring data to regional climate, potentially leading to overestimations in datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The representativeness of tree-ring data in the ITRDB has been questioned due to the specific selection of sampling sites, which may lead to overestimations of regional forest climate sensitivity.

Expectation.Question: Why might current water conditions immediately influence tree growth more significantly than past extreme events, according to dataset analysis expectations?
Expectation.Answer: Current water conditions have a direct and immediate impact on tree growth, potentially altering or offsetting the ecological impacts of past extremes. This is because current growth conditions are rapidly and intensely responsive to changes in interannual water deficit conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How might the representativeness of tree-ring data from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank be improved to better reflect regional climate sensitivity?
Judgmental.Answer: The representativeness of tree-ring data in the ITRDB has been questioned due to specific selection of sampling sites. Updating more metadata, such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment information, of sampled trees can help clarify these uncertainties.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could spatial heterogeneity be accounted for when scaling up tree-ring data to study forest dynamics over larger regions?
Judgmental.Answer: To account for spatial heterogeneity, standard mean scaling of tree-ring chronologies to comparable variance could be employed. Additionally, averaging tree-ring indices within grid cells and designing regional-scale natural experiments can help understand the legacy effects on forest coverage dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure why there is a need for standardizing tree-ring data and what methodology is used for it.
Assertion.Answer: Standardizing tree-ring data is crucial to eliminate long-term trends caused by aging and diameter growth, allowing for a more accurate analysis of climate effects on growth. The ARSTAN program is used, which applies a negative exponential curve to transform tree-ring width data into ring-width indices (RWI), helping to reduce spatial heterogeneity among different sites.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why the representativeness of tree-ring data is questioned.
Assertion.Answer: The representativeness of tree-ring data is questioned because specific sampling sites may lead to an overestimation of regional forest climate sensitivity. To address these uncertainties, it is suggested to update metadata with details like the tree's diameter at breast height and microenvironment information, which could provide a clearer context for interpreting the data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges that may arise when relying on tree-ring data from the International Tree-Ring Data Bank in assessing forest dynamics.
Request/Directive.Answer: The representativeness of tree-ring data in the International Tree-Ring Data Bank (ITRDB) has been questioned due to the specific selection of sampling sites, which may lead to an overestimation of regional forest climate sensitivity. Updating metadata such as diameter at breast height and microenvironment information of sampled trees can help address these uncertainties.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used for matching grid-based water deficit anomaly data with tree-ring width indices and analyze the impact of spatial heterogeneity on this matching process.
Request/Directive.Answer: Grid-based water deficit anomaly (Dya) data were matched with tree-ring width indices (RWI) by averaging tree-ring data within the same grid to reduce bias from coarse climate data resolution. The spatial heterogeneity among tree-ring sites was minimized by standardizing all chronologies to a comparable variance (RWI = 1000).

Request/Directive.Question: Please examine the techniques applied to study the impacts of inter-annual water deficit on forest coverage dynamics and discuss how these techniques account for different hydrological year conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The study employed regional-scaled 'natural experiments' and grouped tree-ring records and forest coverage data based on preset water deficit conditions (normal, wet, or dry) of current and antecedent hydrological years. Forest coverage change (FCC) data were analyzed under these conditions to study inter-annual water deficit impacts on forest dynamics.
